Energy management based on safe multi-agent reinforcement learning for smart buildings in distribution networks Yiyun Sun Writing – original draft Methodology Formal analysis Data curation a Senlin Zhang Writing – review & editing a c Meiqin Liu Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition b a ⁎ Ronghao Zheng Writing – review & editing Methodology a Shanling Dong Writing – review & editing a a College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China College of Electrical Engineering Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310027 China College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China b National Key Laboratory of Human-Machine Hybrid Augmented Intelligence, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, 710049, China National Key Laboratory of Human-Machine Hybrid Augmented Intelligence Xi'an Jiaotong University Xi'an 710049 China National Key Laboratory of Human-Machine Hybrid Augmented Intelligence, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, 710049, China c Jinhua Institute of Zhejiang University, Jinhua, 321036, China Jinhua Institute of Zhejiang University Jinhua 321036 China Jinhua Institute of Zhejiang University, Jinhua, 321036, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China. College of Electrical Engineering Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310027 China The rapid urbanization and increasing use of distributed renewable energy resources have imposed a significant burden on power networks. Smart buildings equipped with artificial intelligence technology can play a pivotal role in energy management, ultimately enhancing energy efficiency and voltage quality. However, ensuring voltage stability within large-scale smart building systems presents challenges due to the coexistence of diverse energy sources and the fluctuating nature of renewable energy. This paper proposes a safe multi-energy management framework achieved by online decentralized execution and centralized training for large scale smart buildings in distribution networks. The energy management problem is formulated as a safety-augmented Markov decision process, presenting intractability for dynamic programming due to its extensive continuous state space. To solve this issue and improve the convergence speed and training process stability, a safety-augmented constrained multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithm based on reward extrapolation is proposed. In this algorithm, hazard values are introduced to enhance non-safe multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithms and meet safety constraints. A novel reward network is designed by imitating expert underlying intentions to ensure the rationality of the reward function for multi-objective tasks. Additionally, the loss function for estimating the Q-network is redesigned during training process to guarantee effective convergence. Theoretical analysis is conducted to provide the convergence guarantee. Numerical case studies based on actual data are performed to validate the effectiveness and scalability of our approach, showing that smart buildings can achieve superior energy management performance while ensuring voltage safety for distribution networks. The source code of the proposed algorithm is available at https://github.com/SYiyun/CMARL-EX. Keywords Intelligent energy management Multi-agent reinforcement learning Smart buildings Safety constraint Imitating learning Data availability I have shared the link to my code in the manuscript file. 1 Introduction The increasing urbanization, integration of additional renewable energy resources, and implementation of energy storage systems pose new control challenges for building energy management in distribution networks [1]. To address these challenges, smart buildings equipped with artificial intelligence technology are proposed for managing energy across distribution networks [2–4]. In order to enhance energy efficiency and ensure occupant comfort in both residential and commercial buildings, the multi-objective optimization algorithm is integrated into smart buildings to interact with standard machine-level controllers for heating, ventilation, air conditioning (HVAC), and photovoltaic (PV) systems [5]. This algorithm defines optimal control parameters based on the current states. The development of dependable control models in smart buildings, based on advanced artificial intelligence technologies, is pivotal in enhancing energy efficiency and voltage stability, establishing the groundwork for the realization of future smart cities [6]. Smart buildings are increasingly recognized as the critical component of the smart city paradigm, serving as hubs of integrated activity within the urban power distribution network [7]. Intelligent energy management task of multiple smart buildings within a distribution network necessitates the efficient integration of behaviors and actions of all connected users, in order to ensure an economical, sustainable, and reliable smart buildings system with reduced losses and enhanced supply security. Given the intricate nature of smart buildings, it is understandable that individual scientific inquiries may focus on specific facets, rather than encompassing the entirety of a smart building's potential [6]. Currently, numerous studies have focused on the energy consumption of smart buildings. For instance, Tolovski et al. in [8] focused on the construction of energy regulation in smart buildings with the objective of shifting peak electricity demand to coincide with periods of peak renewable energy production, thereby reducing net grid consumption. Pigott et al. in [9] centered its construction of smart building energy regulation systems on the assurance of electrical grid voltage safety. Meanwhile, Dey et al. in [3] investigated energy control within smart buildings by holistically considering thermal comfort loss, net grid consumption, and power loss. In summary, the primary focus is to enhance thermal comfort and voltage stability, while simultaneously advancing energy efficiency and reducing carbon emissions. This enhances economic efficiency while ensuring that the thermal comfort of the residents and the reliability of the power grid system are not compromised. Therefore, a real-time automated management system of energy management for smart building systems is required that can not only optimally manage the various components of energy sources, but also consider the system uncertainties and dynamics. Considering the system dynamics of the energy management problem, as well as the shortcomings of optimization-based approaches that require full knowledge of mathematical models and find it difficult to handle uncertainties [10], there is an eagerness to develop a new control algorithm. In the big data era, a model-free and data-driven approach called multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) has been widely applied to many real-world applications [11–14], which is regarded as a valuable alternative approach take place of model-based optimization approach. Instead of adjusting the control variables for each smart building's energy management directly, reinforcement learning (RL) allows an agent to learn from interactions with the environment and gradually acquires the experiences to learn an optimal control policy. In this way, the agent does not require any knowledge of the environment. Previous works have successfully applied various MARL algorithms to demand response and energy management problems of smart buildings in distribution network, which aims to maximize the expected cumulative reward of each agent [15]. Bin Zhang et al. in [16] introduced a attention-based multi-agent soft actor-critic approach for grid-aware multi-buildings energy management, which informs effective and fast control against uncertainties. Jiahan Xie et al. in [17] proposed an MARL approach to leverage real-time system information for optimizing electricity costs and achieving efficient load shaping in grid-responsive buildings. However, there are two main problems associated with implementing MARL for smart buildings within practical power distribution networks. Firstly, there is a lack of security guarantees during the training process [18]. Secondly, it is difficult to ensure the rationality of the reward function to achieve multi-objective optimization [3]. For the first problem mentioned above, the high safety requirements for smart building energy management within power networks, making traditional MARL unsuitable for optimizing energy efficiency with guaranteed safety. Recent advancements in safe MARL have focused on integrating a ‘safety layer’ within policy networks to address voltage violations [19,20]. This layer employs data-driven linear approximations of safety sets to enforce minimal action adjustments that meet safety constraints [20]. Despite its efficacy, this approach is cost-prohibitive for large-scale system control and impractical for high-dimensional spaces, where constructing an explicit safety layer is unfeasible [21]. Reward reshaping has emerged as a solution to reduce computational demands and enhance robustness by harmonizing constraints with reward functions, as seen in MACPO and MAPPO-L [11,22]. However, these approaches cannot guarantee that the soft constraints will never be violated. Songtao Lu's min-max game formulation for constrained policy optimization [23] represents a significant stride, yet it falls short in achieving high task reward performance compared to non-safe MARL algorithms. For the second problem mentioned above, it is necessary to design appropriate target payoff functions. However, designing a reward equation that meets the requirements of multiple objectives poses a significant challenge, as reinforcement learning-based (RL) agents often struggle to learn the desired behavior in a timely manner while adhering to constraints. When RL agents cannot directly access the reward signal, a reasonable reward function can be constructed through imitation learning from the expert [24]. Imitation learning, based on expert data, is an approach to acquire expert policies from demonstrated data. But it has received rare attention in the context of controlling multiple smart buildings. Imitation learning extracts rule-based control behaviors from building data, offering a dependable reward model for online MARL and reducing learning errors. While trajectory-ranked reward extrapolation shows that even suboptimal strategies can outperform expert demonstrations, it is limited to single-agent scenarios [25]. Conversely, multi-agent settings typically require Nash equilibrium solutions, thereby posing additional challenges for reward inference [26]. In this paper, we focus on energy management for smart buildings, where multi-energy devices, such as energy generation, storage, and conversion devices, supply energy to meet users' energy demand. The objective is to optimize the synergistic effect among different energy carriers within a multi-energy system. Considering the practical application needs for energy regulation safety and high-reward performance in MARL-based smart building systems, a more general safe MARL framework with high reward performance for energy management in large-scale buildings is still lacking at this stage. To fill this gap, the large-scale multi-agent building energy management problem is formulated as a safety-augmented Markov decision process (MDP). The CMARL-EX method, designed to address safety-augmented MDP, not only secures voltage stability but also elucidates control strategies with satisfied regulation performance. This approach significantly improves the efficiency and stability of the training process compared to prior methods [3,19,20,22]. The contributions of this paper are described as follows: 1) To address the energy management challenges in smart building systems, this paper introduces a novel, model-free framework for multi-energy management. This framework combines centralized training at the energy management center with decentralized execution at each smart building, and the center assists in formulating joint energy management policies for each smart building. 2) Addressing unregulated voltage fluctuations in energy management, this study presents an MARL-based framework that enhances safety without increasing computational demands, a notable advancement over traditional models lacking in voltage security and scalability. The framework's novel reward reshaping approach strengthens safety protocols efficiently, setting it apart from more computationally intensive methods [19,20]. 3) Current safe MARL-based energy regulation approaches struggle to guarantee convergence during training process [20]. We propose a modified loss function target estimation for the Q-network during training. The targeted value is determined through the competition of the immediate reward estimate and the output of the target network, resulting in a stable target value to ensure safety while maintaining performance. 4) Contrasting with approaches like those in [22,23,27], which yield suboptimal rewards, our method incorporates reward extrapolation within constrained MARL training. This approach mimics underlying intentions using trajectory data from expert controller demonstrations, enhancing policy stability and promoting smoother learning curves during training. The paper is structured as follows: Section 2 presents the theoretical foundations of constrained MARL; Section 3 introduces a smart power distribution network system with energy models of smart buildings and formulates the energy management problem; Section 4 presents the design of the proposed safe constrained multi-agent deep reinforcement learning algorithm based on reward extrapolation. The simulation results for the actual data are presented in Section 5. Section 6 concludes the remarks of this paper. 2 Preliminary In this section, some theoretical preliminaries on constrained MARL and imitation learning method are reviewed. 2.1 Constrained multi-agent reinforcement learning We begin by examining fundamental concepts in MARL and MDP. Additionally, we modify some definitions to align with our specific context. Definition 1 A MARL problem is often defined as an MDP M = ( N , S , A , R , P , γ r , ρ 0 ) , where N = { 1 , … , N } represents the set of agents, S is the set of observed joint states, γ r ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) denotes the task discount factor, A = × k ∈ N A k is the set of joint actions, R = { R k } 1 ≤ k ≤ N : S × A → R represents the task reward function where R k is the reward function for each agent, P : S × A × S → R is the probabilistic transition function, and ρ 0 signifies the distribution of the initial environmental state. We associate the following optimization problem with the MDP, aiming to maximize the expected reward of each agent k: (1) max π ⁡ E s π J ( π ) ≜ max π k , 1 ≤ k ≤ N ⁡ E s π k [ ∑ t = 0 ∞ γ r t R k ( s t , a k , t ) | a k , t ∼ π k ] where π is the joint policy, and in Eq. (1) we seek the best policy π k for agent k while considering the policy π − k of other agents. To solve the optimization problem, the state-action value function for each agent k is defined as Q k π ( s , a 1 , . . . , a N ) | a k = π k ( s k ) , and the task is to find optimal joint policy that satisfies: (2) π ⁎ ( s ) = arg ⁡ max a k ∈ A , 1 ≤ k ≤ N ⁡ Q k ⁎ ( s , a 1 , . . . , a N ) Multi-agent deep deterministic policy gradient method (MADDPG) represents a promising and notable approach [28]. MADDPG incorporates individual actor-critic networks for N agents, and each agent possesses its own online actor and critic network. Consider that numerous safety-critical applications require fulfillment of constraints. Now we can move on to constrained MDP (C-MDP). Definition 2 A MARL problem with safety constraints is commonly defined as a C-MDP, denoted by M c = ( N , S , A , R , P , C , D , γ r , γ c , ρ 0 ) . Here, γ c ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) represents the safety discount factor. The set C = { C k j } 1 ≤ k ≤ N , 1 ≤ j ≤ m k defines the collection of cost-constraining functions, where each agent k has m k cost functions, and D = { d k j } 1 ≤ k ≤ N , 1 ≤ j ≤ m k represents the set of safety budgets. At each time step t, every agent k selects an action a k , t , forming the joint action as a t = { a 1 , t , … , a k , t } . Subsequently, joint rewards R ( s t , a t ) and safety costs C k j ( s t , a k , t ) for each agent k can be computed. The associated optimization problem of each agent k is: (3) max π ⁡ E s π J ( π ) ≜ max π k , 1 ≤ k ≤ N ⁡ E s π k [ ∑ t = 0 ∞ γ r t R k ( s t , a k , t ) | a k , t ∼ π k ] s . t . : E s π k [ d k j − ∑ t = 0 ∞ γ c t C k j ( s t , a k , t ) ] ≥ 0 where π : × k ∈ N π k is the joint policy, and the nonnegative value d k j ∈ D is the safety budget for constraint j of agent k. The mean of the cumulative cost could be substituted with an alternative statistical measure. For instance, the problem can be reformulated as: max π k , 1 ≤ k ≤ N ⁡ E s π k [ ∑ t = 0 ∞ γ r t R k ( s t , a k , t ) | a k , t ∼ π k ] + λ E s π k [ d k j − ∑ t = 0 ∞ γ c t C k ( s t , a k , t ) ] (4) λ = { 0 if E s π k [ d k j − ∑ t = 0 ∞ γ c t C k ( s t , a k , t ) ] ≥ 0 , N C if E s π k [ d k j − ∑ t = 0 ∞ γ c t C k ( s t , a k , t ) ] < 0 . where N C is a large non-negative value. 2.2 Imitation learning method A key limitation of MARL lies in the challenge associated with devising appropriate reward functions for complex tasks with implicit objectives, and inappropriate reward functions in MARL can indeed result in slow convergence or difficulties in achieving convergence. Imitation learning provides a useful approach for programming agents by leveraging expert demonstrations (e.g. rule-based control) on achieving implicit objectives. Specifically, multi-agent imitation learning aims to train multiple agents to accomplish tasks based on demonstrations, by acquiring the ability to map observations and actions, which plays a crucial role in multi-agent systems. Trajectory-ranked reward extrapolation method (TREX) is an imitation learning approach [25]. It focuses on inferring the potential intentions of users by leveraging ranked demonstrations. This method allows agents to learn joint policy that go beyond what is explicitly demonstrated by the demonstrator, while accelerating the convergence rate. More specifically, for single agent reinforcement learning, given a sequence of l ranked trajectories τ ≜ { X 1 , . . , X l } = { [ s 1 , a 1 ] , . . , [ s l , a l ] } , where X i ≺ X j for i < j , and ≺ represents the expert preference relationship between pairwise expert trajectories. TREX aims to forecast the cumulative payoff of trajectories and classify paired trajectories ( X i , X j ) to discern the potential optimization objectives of experts. The classifier's objective function is formulated as cross-entropy: (5) L ( θ ) = − ∑ X i ≺ X j log ⁡ exp ⁡ R θ ( X j ) exp ⁡ R θ ( X i ) + exp ⁡ R θ ( X j ) where R θ is the evaluation function of the state-action tensor X , based on which the reward function is generated. 3 System model In this section, a smart power distribution network system with energy models of smart buildings is provided. The energy management problem formulation is given as well. 3.1 Power distribution network system We consider an electric power distribution network system including 9 heterogeneous smart buildings with 5 energy models: air-to-water heat pump air conditioner, electric heater, PV, thermal storage and battery, as shown in Fig. 1 [9]. The building models are constructed on the DOE prototype buildings. 1 1 https://www.energycodes.gov/prototype-building-models. The chosen building types are summarized in Table 1 . Specifically, the electricity is sourced from a power plant and then transmitted through specialized transmission lines. Multi-stage transformers are utilized to reduce the voltage levels as the electricity is transported to the distribution network. Subsequently, occupants in smart buildings consume the electricity. The PV unit in the smart building (shown in Fig. 1(e)) consists of PV panels and smart voltage-source inverters. To meet the comfort needs (temperature setpoints and domestic hot water (DHW) demand) of occupants in smart buildings, U.S. Energy collected architectural data from numerous real buildings and computed energy loads of smart building models from pre-simulated models at 15-minute intervals [9,29]. It operates under the assumption that the indoor temperature remains unaffected by controller actions. Consequently, the heating and cooling energy requirements of the smart building are consistently satisfied, irrespective of the controller's interventions. To effectively coordinate the energy exchange between each smart building and the main grid, meanwhile meeting building occupant's demand response and educing carbon emissions, it is significant to find a energy management policy. In this paper, MARL (where each smart building is controlled through a RL agent) is used to achieve demand response goals while ensuring the security of the power grid. Success can be measured by metrics such as achieving voltage stability, reducing power losses, and minimizing net energy consumption. 3.2 Energy model in smart building In this section, the energy devices for smart building k ∈ N are modeled. For case of reference, the nomenclature is summarized in Table 2 . Each smart building k is composed of a heat pump air conditioner, an electric heater, a PV unit, a thermal storage unit (comprising cooling storage and heating storage), and a battery. This configuration is referred to as: (6) C t + 1 , k = C t , k + max ⁡ { min ⁡ { a k , t C × G k C , Q t , k , m a x C o o l } , − Q t , k , d e C o o l } (7) D t + 1 , k = D t , k + max ⁡ { min ⁡ { a k , t D × G k D , Q t , k , m a x H e a t } , − Q t , k , d e H e a t } (8) Q t + 1 , k C = G k C ( C t + 1 , k − C t , k ) + Q t , k , d e C o o l (9) Q t + 1 , k H = G k D ( D t + 1 , k − D t , k ) + Q t , k , d e H e a t (10) E t + 1 , k = E t , k + min ⁡ { a k , t E × G k E , Q t , k , m a x E } (11) E k , t n e t = ( E k b − R t , k − min ⁡ { a k , t E × G k E , Q t , k , m a x E } ) (12) G k C ≥ 0 (13) − 1 / G k C ≤ a k , t C ≤ 1 / G k C (14) G k D ≥ 0 (15) − 1 / G k D ≤ a k , t D ≤ 1 / G k D (16) G k E ≥ 0 (17) − 1 / G k E ≤ a k , t E ≤ 1 / G k E (18) Q t , k , d e C o o l ≥ 0 (19) Q t , k , d e H e a t ≥ 0 where Eqs. (6)–(7) denote the model of the cooling storage and heating storage, Eqs. (8)–(9) denote the model of the cooling device (i.e., heat pump air conditioner) and heating device (i.e., electric heater), Eq. (10) denotes the model of the battery, and smart inverters with phase lag control a k p are added to smart buildings with DC resources (PV, battery) [37]. At each time step t, each smart building k is supplied with thermal energy from the thermal storage tanks and/or an energy supply unit such as a heat pump air conditioner or an electric heater. If the storage device is going to be charged/discharged, the energy supply device will always prioritize meeting the energy demand of the smart building first. Besides, EnergyPlus weather file is used to determine PV power production, and the phase lag of the smart inverter is used to scale the active and reactive power supplied by the PV and battery. 3.3 Grid environment Grid models and AC power flows are modeled by pandapower [30]. The pandapower calculates real and reactive power at each bus, load, and generator along with voltages at each bus. In this study, we used a preconfigured IEEE 33-bus network model [9] and a custom 86-bus network constructed based on the XiaZhai substation in northern Hebei province of China. 3.4 Problem formulation For a smart grid system with N smart building units, the objective of energy management is to seek the optimal energy management policy for each energy model while satisfying voltage safety constraints. Success is measured by minimizing system voltage fluctuations, reactive power losses, and net energy consumption. The problem is formulated as follows: (20) min π ⁡ J t a s k ( π ) = min π k , 1 ≤ k ≤ N ⁡ E s π k [ ∑ t = 0 T γ r t B k ( s t , a k , t ) | a k , t ∼ π k ] s . t . E s π k [ ∑ t = 0 T γ c t V k o u t ( s t , a k , t ) | a k , t ∼ π k ] = 0 where V k o u t is the uncontrolled voltage measured on the bus where the smart building unit k is located, and B k ( ⋅ ) is the task cost function of smart building unit k. The task cost function considering multiple performance indicators is given by: (21) B k ( s t , a k , t ) | a k , t ∼ π k = w 1 V d , k w 2 + w 3 P l , k w 4 + w 5 f p r i c e P c , k w 6 where the nomenclature is summarized in Table 2. When the voltage remains stable within a safe range, the attention given to voltage fluctuations in energy distribution tasks is significantly lower compared to the attention given when voltage becomes uncontrolled. Simultaneously, the importance of net energy consumption and power losses during the peak and off-peak periods of PV generation differs significantly. The weights w 1 , w 2 , w 3 , w 4 , w 5 , w 6 need to be reasonably varied over time to ensure their importance in the objective function. 4 Constrained multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithm based on reward extrapolation To solve the above-mentioned energy management problem, a safety-augmented constrained multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithm based on reward extrapolation (CMARL-EX) is proposed. 4.1 C-MDP description In the CMARL-EX algorithm, smart building units in the smart grid run MADDPG algorithm. For a smart grid system with N smart building units, a C-MDP can be defined as M c = ( N , S , A , R , P , C , D , γ r , γ c , ρ 0 ) , which is described in detail as follows. 1) State The observed state s k , t of each agent consists of multiple state variables. • s m o n : Month of the year (1-12) • s t i m e : Time of the day (1-96), where 15-minute interval is set as the time-step • s t y p e : Day type variable • s t i n : Average indoor temperature of the smart building • s t o u t : Outdoor temperature • s t p r e d : The predicted outdoor temperature after 6 hours • s e q u : Electricity consumption • s V o b : The absolute voltage at the nearest bus • s V r e : The relative voltage at the nearest bus • s R g e : The current average power generation • s C o o l : The SOC of the cooling storage device • s H e a t : The SOC of the heating storage device • s E : The SOC of the electrical storage 2) Action The cooling energy storage a k C , heating energy storage a k D , electric storage a k E and the phase lag control a k p with DC resources are set as the actions of smart building unit k at each time, which is donated as a ≜ [ a k C , a k D , a k E , a k p ] . 3) Reward The instant reward of smart building unit k depends on the objective function and local constraints, defined as: (22) R k = − B k ( s t , a k , t ) | a k , t ∼ π k = − w 1 V d , k w 2 − w 3 P l , k w 4 − w 5 f p r i c e P c , k w 6 4) Energy management problem formution We model the smart building energy management system, aiming to maximizing the individual benefits of each smart building. The objective function is defined as: (23) max π ⁡ J ( π ) = max π k , 1 ≤ k ≤ N ⁡ E s π k [ ∑ t = 0 ∞ γ r t ( − B k ( s t , a k , t ) | a k , t ∼ π k ) ] s . t . : E s π k [ d k − ∑ t = 0 ∞ γ c t C k ( s t , a k , t ) ] ≥ 0 where π : × k ∈ N π k is the joint policy, and the non-negative value d k ∈ D is the safety budget for constraint of agent k. This problem can be rewritten as an equivalent max-min problem using the Lagrangian approach [31]: (24) max π ⁡ min λ ≥ 0 ⁡ J ˆ ≜ max π k , 1 ≤ k ≤ N ⁡ min λ ≥ 0 ⁡ E s π k [ ∑ t = 0 ∞ γ r t R k ( s t , a k , t ) | a k , t ∼ π k ] + λ E s π k [ d k j − ∑ t = 0 ∞ γ c t C k ( s t , a k , t ) ] where C k ( ⋅ ) is defined as the function measuring the voltage approaching the safety threshold on the bus where the smart building unit k is located. Then for centralized training with decentralized execution (CTDE) algorithms, as shown in Eq. (24), additional value function is estimated to track the safety cost. It is not clear if the optimal policy can be found, as it is unclear how the Bellman equation translates in the context of constraints. 4.2 Safety-augmented constrained multi-agent reinforcement learning Inspired by the state-augmentation method [24], we strive to transform safety constraints into safety-enhanced states and reshape the reward function. We extend this approach to the MARL framework, enabling secure reinforcement learning. Consider the energy management problem in Eq. (4) with voltage safety constraints and joint reward, a finite number of constraints needed to be satisfied: (25) ∑ t = 0 T γ c t C k ( s t , a k , t ) ≤ d k When an agent violates a voltage safety constraint at a specific moment t 0 , it enters a hazardous zone for subsequent time points t > t 0 . Thus, we integrate constraints as safety costs within the instantaneous time for ensuring safety during task resolution. In the multi-agent case, we assign a hazard value to each constraint of agent k, donated as: (26) h k , t = ( d k − ∑ t = 0 T γ c t C k ( s t , a k , t ) ) / γ c t For simplicity, we use the notation h t for the vector ( h 0 , t , . . . , h k , t , . . . , h N , t ) , and the hazard value h t has an updated expression: (27) h k , t + 1 = ( h k , t − C k ( s t , a k , t ) ) / γ c , h k , 0 = d k . Since the variable h t is Markovian, the reward of task can be reshaped to account for the safety constraint: (28) R ˜ k ( s t , h t , a k , t ) = { R k ( s t , a k , t ) h k , t ≥ 0 , − N c h k , t < 0 . Finally, we can formalize the problem to: (29) max π k , 1 ≤ k ≤ N ⁡ E s π k [ ∑ t = 0 ∞ γ r t ( R ˜ k ( s t , h t , a k , t ) | a k , t ∼ π k ] s . t . s t + 1 ∼ P ( ⋅ | s t , h t , a t , 1 , . . . , a t , N ) h k , t + 1 = ( h k , t − C ( s t , a k , t ) ) / γ c h k , 0 = d k . Then we provide definition of safety-augmented multi-agent MDP. Definition 3 Given a C-MDP M c = ( N , S , A , R , P , C , D , γ r , γ c , ρ 0 ) for addressing the energy management problem in smart buildings, we define a safety-augmented MDP (safe-MDP) as a tuple: M ˜ c = ( N , S , A , h , R ˜ , P ˜ , γ r , ρ 0 ) . Here, h : × k ∈ N h k represents the set of hazard values, and h k : S → R assigns hazard values to states. The task reward function R ˜ ≜ { R ˜ k } 1 ≤ k ≤ N defines rewards R ˜ k for each agent k, with P ˜ being the probabilistic transition function. We associate the problem in Eq. (29) with safety-augmented multi-agent MDP. To summarize, the proposed safe augmented method has effectively showed the following Theorem 1, and proof of Theorem 1 is given in Appendix A. Theorem 1 The optimal joint policy π ⁎ for Eq. (29) is also an optimal joint policy for Eq. (1) problem. 4.3 Reward functions construction via reward extrapolation For the multi-objective optimization energy management problem, it is difficult to design reasonable rewards. Besides, agents can hardly learn the desired behavior of people expect, which leads to extensive exploration behavior and long training times in MARL settings. As shown in Eq. (22), the reward function of energy management problem requires 6 parameters ( w 1 − w 6 ). Inappropriate parameter settings can result in a significant amount of risky behavior during online learning, which is unacceptable for distribution network systems. To solve the prolonged training time and early-stage instability in constrained MARL, we propose a imitation learning method to expedite the training process. Inspired by reward extrapolation method [25], we adopt a rule-based control policy based on historical data as an expert policy, then attempt to infer the underlying intentions of the system and construct an task reward function through the ranked expert demonstrations, instead of directly specifying a task reward function. More specifically, given a sequence of L ranked trajectories τ = { τ e 1 , τ e 2 , . . . , τ e L } , each agent uses a neural network to predict the joint payoff R θ ( τ e i ) for the trajectory state τ e i ∈ τ . For simplicity, we use the notation τ e i for the tuple ( [ s e i , a e i , 1 ] , [ s e i , a e i , 2 ] , … , [ s e i , a e i , N ] ) , and R θ for the tuple ( R θ , 1 , R θ , 2 , . . R θ , N ) . Then we perform reward inference in a manner that indicates ∑ R θ ( τ e i ) < ∑ R θ ( τ e j ) when τ e i ≺ τ e j , ≺ represents the expert preference relationship between the pairwise trajectories. The reward function R θ can be trained by employing ranked expert trajectory and the utilization of the generalized loss function: (30) L ( θ ) = E τ e i , τ e j ∼ τ [ ξ ( P ( J ˆ θ ( τ e i ) < J ˆ θ ( τ e j ) ) ) , τ e i ≺ τ e j ] where ξ is the binary classification loss function, and J ˆ θ is the cumulative team payoff calculated by the reward function R θ . We employ cross entropy as the classification loss function, where J ˆ θ is utilized to compute the softmax normalized probability distribution P: (31) P ( J ˆ θ ( τ e i ) < J ˆ θ ( τ e j ) ) ≈ exp ⁡ ∑ R θ ( τ e j ) exp ⁡ ∑ R θ ( τ e j ) + exp ⁡ ∑ R θ ( τ e i ) The loss function can be donated as: (32) L ( θ ) = − ∑ τ e i ≺ τ e j log ⁡ exp ⁡ ∑ R θ ( τ e j ) exp ⁡ ∑ R θ ( τ e j ) + exp ⁡ ∑ R θ ( τ e i ) Then, we can get the joint payoff R θ ( τ e k ) from the expert trajectory. The optimization objective for agent k can be formulated as: max π k ⁡ E s π k [ ∑ t = 0 ∞ γ r t R θ , k ( τ k ) | τ k ∼ π k ] . The reward function is the payoff value of the neural network's prediction for the global state s and agents' action { a k } k = 1 N . By utilizing information from the state-action feedback at each moment, the reward function can expedite the learning process and attain a joint policy that surpasses expert trajectories. This is achieved by learning the intended optimization objectives directly from the expert. 4.4 CMARL-EX algorithm process For an N-agent smart power network system, the proposed CMARL-EX algorithm includes a pre-training module, a reward function network module and a safe-MDP execution module. The CMARL-EX method, compared to the traditional safe-MDP learning method, incorporates a pre-training module and a reward function network module to ensure the safety of the energy management training process and to generate accurate and effective regulation strategies. The design of the reward function is crucial for generating accurate and effective scheduling strategies. However, the quality of the reward signal is influenced by multiple factors such as training duration and the number of training iterations, making it difficult to intuitively represent [32]. For instance, in the case of the inherent scarcity of renewable energy, even with the maximum output of a limited-size energy storage system, additional electricity must be imported from the main grid to ensure an uninterrupted supply. Nevertheless, if the consumer electricity cost weight is significant in the agent's reward, the reward associated with the energy storage system is unlikely to contribute to a ‘sustained’ training process in the aforementioned scenario. Moreover, the significance of different objectives is distinguished across various training phases. In the stage where voltage fluctuations have stabilized, the design of the reward function should prioritize consumer electricity cost within the objective function over voltage deviation [3,32]. Therefore, learning the reward function network from expert data helps accelerate the energy management training process and ensures policy performance. What's more, the pre-trained model capitalizes on existing knowledge derived from rule-based data and further refines its policy via continuous interaction. This approach circumvents the need for training from inception, concurrently mitigating the exploratory instability and sample inefficiency typically associated with MARL training. For example, Lissa et al. in [33] reduced the training time needed to learn a near-optimal policy by a factor of five using a shared learning experience. For online MARL learning scenarios with high safety requirements in energy regulation, parameter transfer based on pre-trained models is crucial. Despite the increase in computational complexity, this method significantly shortens the training time and provides a favorable initial learning curve, as elaborated in Section 5. The CMARL-EX algorithm is implemented using the following steps. 1) Initialization of each agent k: Agent k random initializes estimation critic network Q k ( s , h , a , ω Q k c u r ) , estimation actor network μ k ( s k , ω μ k c u r ) and reward network R θ k ( s , h , a k ) . The target critic network Q k ( s , h , a , ω Q k t a r ) , target actor network μ k ( s k , ω μ k t a r ) copies the weights ω Q c u r and ω μ c u r . 2) Reward function imitation learning: In the pre-process step, rule-based control is used as the expert strategy, and expert trajectories τ is generated based on historical data. For each pair of expert trajectory data { τ e i , τ e j } in the mini-batch, reward function networks R θ are trained by Eq. (30). 3) Pre-training: Supervised learning is performed with the agent's network parameters ( ω Q and ω μ ) in MADDPG to predict the Q-values Q k ( s , h , a ) and the safety hazard value h k ( s , a ) of the expert trajectory points such that h k ( s , a ) ≥ 0 . This state-action value learned by the RL agent will generate a policy that is likely to mimic rule-based actions before online training. This knowledge transferred from expert trajectory data is intended to reduce the unstable exploratory training behavior. 4) Online training: In each online time-step, the safe-MDP execution module of each agent k observes the states s k , calculates the instant reward r k using R θ k , and reshapes it to obtain r ˜ k through R ˜ θ k in Eq. (28) for safety constraints. The subsequent state s t + 1 is obtained from the current environment. Agent k then encapsulates the tuple ( s k , t , h k , t , a k , t , r ˜ k , t + 1 , s k , t + 1 ) generated at each time-step and stores it in its replay buffer ℵ before proceeding to the subsequent episode. 5) Each agent conducts a mini-batch training using a randomly selected batch S b of size b from the replay buffer ℵ to update the weights of the neural networks. For each data point ( s k , t , h k , t , a k , t , r ˜ k , t + 1 , s k , t + 1 ) in the mini-batch, the loss function for the estimation Q-network is calculated as: (33) L ( ω Q k c u r ) = E [ y k , t − Q k ( s t , h t , a t , ω Q k c u r ) ] 2 and the modified target value y k , t is defined by the target value competition, which yields: (34) y k , t ← max ⁡ ( v k , t c , v k , t e ) , v k , t c = R ˜ k ( s t , h t , a k , t , θ k ) + γ max ⁡ Q k ( s t + 1 , h t + 1 , a t + 1 , ω Q k t a r ) , v k , t e = Q k ( s t , h t , a t , ω Q k t a r ) where the Q-network's target value is determined by comparing the current learning target value, denoted as v k , t c , with the target value estimated from past experience, denoted as v k , t e . The higher of the two is chosen as the Q-network's target value. Fig. 2 provides a visual representation of the entire process alongside Algorithm 1 , which summarizes the corresponding pseudocode. 4.5 Theoretical analysis The proof of the convergence of MARL is a big challenging at present. The difficulty in theoretical reasoning arises from the non-linear activation functions of deep neural networks. We denote M ˜ c = ( N , S , A , h , R ˜ , P ˜ , γ r , ρ 0 ) as an MDP. Since MADDPG adopts perturbed actions through the actor network μ k ( s k , ω μ k ) , there are always random processes in the MDP M ˜ c . The following lemma is provided in [34]. Lemma 1 A random process { Δ t } → R n is defined as: (35) Δ t + 1 ( x ) = ξ F t ( x ) + ( 1 − ξ ) Δ t ( x ) The proposed random process converges to 0 under the specified conditions. 1) ‖ E [ F ( t ) | E ( t ) ] ‖ w ≤ γ 1 ‖ Δ t ( x ) ‖ w ; 2) v a r [ F ( t ) | E ( t ) ] ≤ γ 2 ( 1 + ‖ Δ t ( x ) ‖ w 2 ) , with γ 2 > 0 ; 3) 0 ≤ ξ ≤ 1 where E ( t ) represents the past at time step t, while the notation ‖ ⋅ ‖ w denotes a weighted maximum norm. To demonstrate the effectiveness of proposed CMARL-EX, we will verify the conditions of Lemma 1 one by one. Firstly, for an N-agent system, we give the following assumption. Assumption 1 Assuming that for each agent k, every state-action pair ( s , a k ) has a unique optimal action combination and optimal reward, denoted as ( s , a k ⁎ ) and R ˜ k ( s , h , a k ⁎ ) . At each certain time step t, the following theorem is provided, and the corresponding proof can be found in Appendix B. Theorem 2 For safe-constrained MARL with target value competition, the condition R ˜ k ( s t , h t , a k , t ) ≤ R ˜ k ( s t , h t , a ⁎ k , t ) holds in the learning process, where R ˜ k ( s t , h t , a k , t ) is any reward of ( s t , h t , a k , t ) , and R ˜ k ( s t , h t , a ⁎ k , t ) is the reward for the optimal Q-function value. Thus the condition R ˜ k ( s t , h t , a k , t ) ≤ R ˜ k ( s t , h t , a ⁎ k , t ) holds for any state-action pair ( s t , h t , a k , t ) in the learning process, and then we get the following theorem. The proof of Theorem 3 can be found in Appendix C. Theorem 3 The proposed safe-constrained MARL learning can obtain the optimal policy π ⁎ . According to Assumption 1, Theorem 2 and Theorem 3, it can be inferred that the value function derived from value iteration is the optimal value function [35,36]. Consequently, the optimal joint policy π ⁎ can be obtained. 5 Case studies In this section, two case studies are built for energy management of smart multi-buildings in distribution networks. Then several experiments are conducted to test the effectiveness and scalability of proposed CMARL-EX algorithm. 5.1 Preliminary Before initiating the establishment of case studies, the indicators for evaluating the task objective of energy regulation are established. There are three evaluation metrics for task objective, which are all defined as the reward function shown in Eq. (22): (1) Average voltage deviation V d [9] : It is expressed as the average voltage deviations away from 1 p.u. over all buses per time step. (2) Net electricity consumption P C [4,37] : It calculates the total net electricity consumption per time step. (3) Reactive power loss P L [4,37] : It calculates the average reactive power loss of each bus per time step. Besides, safety cost functions of the environment can be defined to ensure that the observed voltage at each voltage bus remains within the safe range ( 0.95 p.u. ≤ v k ≤ 1.05 p.u. ) [9,18]. We add the following safety cost for this environment: (36) C k ( v k ) = { 0.2 + 500 × ( | v ˆ k | − 0.05 ) if 0.05 < | v ˆ k | 2 × 10 3 ( | v ˆ k | − 0.04 ) 2 if 0.04 < | v ˆ k | ≤ 0.05 0 if | v ˆ k | ≤ 0.04 where | v ˆ k | = | v k − 1 | , and v k is the observed voltage corresponds to the bus connected to smart building unit k. Additionally, a fixed value of d k = 1 is assigned to every smart building k. 5.2 Case study 1 5.2.1 Simulation setup In this case study, we have two datasets D d a t a 1 and D d a t a 2 . The dataset D d a t a 1 is the building history data of one month based on building model provided in Section 3.2, which is used for the offline learning process in Section 4.3. Specifically, we generate expert historical trajectories based on D d a t a 1 and the rule-based control strategies from [9]. To accomplish our task objectives, the preference scoring and ranking are performed using Eq. (22) based on expert preferences. The dataset D d a t a 2 is four weeks (28 days) of random summer days in Hawaiian climate zone, which we use for online training and testing process. IEEE 33-bus distribution network is used in this study as a grid model and simulated it with the pandapower library. The IEEE 33-bus network is illustrated in Fig. 3 [9]. For each of the 32 distribution buses, one type of building is randomly assigned to each bus. 5.2.2 Algorithm training performance analysis To verify the effectiveness of CMARL-EX for online training process on power distribution network system. We conduct experiments on three algorithms: standard CMARL, CMARL-EX and CMARL-EXNE without target value competition. Additionally, we employ the average task reward R ¯ calculated using Eq. (22), and the average safety cost C ¯ determined through Eq. (36) as assessment metrics to evaluate the algorithm training performance. The progress of the RL agents during training is shown in Fig. 4 . The figure displays a 14-day moving average of the rewards and safety costs during the training process. Compared to the direct training approach, all algorithms with safety constraints can provide succeeded in decreasing the uncontrolled voltage and providing a safer process during training. Besides, with using the target value competition and reward exploration, RL agents training progress showcases a faster convergence speed as well as a much more stable performance, especially during the initial training phase. To conduct a comprehensive analysis of the roles played by the target value competition and reward exploration. We conduct optimization experiments. Fig. 5 displays a 1-day moving average of the rewards and safety costs during the online training process. Compared with Fig. 5 (a) and Fig. 5 (b), the total training performance exhibits a significant improvement. It can be revealed that for the problem with cost uncertainty, estimating rewards proves advantageous in facilitating neural networks' approximation of value spaces. Besides, target value competition effectively mitigates the instability. As shown in Fig. 6 , the CMARL-EX algorithm effectively mitigates the overlimit voltage in the initial phase of training, particularly during peak periods. This is crucial for guaranteeing voltage safety and stable operation for smart buildings while engaging with the real-world power network. 5.2.3 System regulation performance comparison To verify the effectiveness of the regulation strategy for energy management on large-scale power grid system, online execution strategy from training model is compared with the baseline regulation algorithms. We test solution strategy regulation performance on the test data in 32-agent case. In experiments, we use six metrics to measure the performance of algorithms. Among them, three metrics are used to directly trained by reward in Eq. (22), defined in Section 5.1. Besides, three additional metrics are established to more rigorously assess the algorithm's regulation performance, but do not directly contribute to the construction of the reward in Eq. (22): (1) Execution time T e ( ms ) : It is used to denote the duration of each step of the regulation strategy, serving as an indicator of the execution efficiency of the energy management method. (2) Moving Average V ( p . u . ) : It is expressed as average observed voltage over all buses per time step. (3) Total line loss P T L ( kWh ) : It calculates the average of the total power loss over all buses per time step. We expect our results to have low average voltage deviation, low net electricity consumption, low uncontrollable rate, low reactive power loss and shorter execution time. Meanwhile, the observed voltage always remains within the safety limits. We test the strategy performance of various algorithms on the proposed case study, where the expert strategy uses rule-based control (RBC) and the centralized optimization algorithm employs optimal power flow control (OPF). Considering the expensive cost of multi-agent strategy interaction in evolution, we only evolve 1000 epochs based on dataset D d a t a 2 , each epoch containing 96 steps (i.e., 24 hours). As shown in Table 3 and Fig. 7 , the strategy trained by CMARL-EX outperforms other algorithms in terms of average voltage deviation measure, net electricity consumption measure, and power loss measure. The results indicate that the proposed distributed execution CMARL-EX algorithm in this paper can also achieve the same satisfactory results as the centralized approach (OPF). Moreover, in contrast to the directly evolved direct MADDPG algorithm, the CMARL-EX and CMARL-EXNE algorithms, which incorporate a pre-training stage, can guarantee safety during the initial training phase without compromising the efficiency of strategic evolution and convergence. Although the pre-training phase conducted offline introduces an element of complexity to the algorithm, it significantly contributes to the online training and execution process, ensuring that the algorithm fulfills the task objectives while maintaining safety standards. When compared to the CMARL algorithm that lacks the incorporation of imitation learning, the strategy trained by CMARL-EX demonstrates accelerated convergence and exhibits a higher propensity to culminate in a superior performing strategy. Furthermore, the CMARL-EX algorithm still performs well on the indirect regulation metrics V and P T L , as shown in Fig. 7d and Fig. 7e. This suggests that the algorithm is capable of emulating the underlying intent of expert joint policies for energy management, thereby deriving a joint policy that surpasses the expert approach. It is worth noting that the strategy trained by CMARL-EX demonstrates a reduction in execution speed T e when compared to the RBC baseline and direct MADDPG algorithm. This is primarily attributed to the structural enhancement of our CMARL-EX algorithm, which incorporates an additional reward function estimation network, thereby increasing computational complexity. Nevertheless, it surpasses other algorithms with respect to average voltage deviation, net electricity consumption, and power loss metrics. Overall, a marginal increase in execution time, measured in milliseconds, is tolerable to achieve the algorithm's targeted performance and to ensure the safety and reliability of online training. Table 4 presents the regulation performance of various MARL algorithms, including the proposed CMARL-EX, MADDPG [28], IPPO [38], and CMA-QMIX [10], over a 28-day period using dataset D d a t a 2 . The result suggests that the CMARL-EX approach incurs only a nominal slowdown in execution speed when compared with the IPPO algorithm and direct MADDPG. Nonetheless, it consistently outstrips the comparative MARL algorithms in performance. The integration of CMARL methodologies with reward extrapolation presents an effective pathway towards the realization of trustworthy MARL. 5.2.4 System regulation performance in ecologically disturbed locales The results in Section 5.2.3 corroborate the efficacy of the CMARL-EX algorithm, which demonstrates enhanced outcomes on a multitude of objective indices when compared to existing advanced algorithms. However, in locales subject to ecological disturbances, the formulation of energy management strategies for smart building systems necessitates a comprehensive approach that prioritizes green, eco-friendly, and sustainable practices [6,39]. Consequently, energy regulation strategies in smart building design must place a heightened emphasis on carbon emissions, aiming to achieve efficient carbon reduction. To verify the efficacy and robustness of the proposed algorithm, we extend our analysis to include the new experiment aimed at curtailing carbon emissions, thus advancing efforts to alleviate the impact of the greenhouse effect. Unlike the objective function defined in Eq. (22), we redefine the objective function to prioritize carbon emission reduction for each building while maintaining the stability and security of the distributed power grid system. The carbon emission factor data are derived from a dynamic electricity carbon emission factor dataset that reflects real-time variations specific to the Hawaiian climate zone, 2 2 https://sites.google.com/view/citylearnchallenge/. as shown in Fig. 8 . The new task cost function is formulated as follows: (37) B ˆ k ( s t , a k , t ) | a k , t ∼ π k = w ˆ 1 V d , k w ˆ 2 + w ˆ 3 P T L , k w ˆ 4 + w ˆ 5 f c a r b o n P c , k w ˆ 6 where f c a r b o n is the carbon emission factor for each time step. P l is defined as the reactive power loss per step, P T L is the total line loss over all buses per time step during each step, V d is the average voltage deviation per step, and the parameters w ˆ 1 to w ˆ 6 represent the weight coefficients. Then, the objective function can be defined as: (38) max π ⁡ J ( π ) = max π k , 1 ≤ k ≤ N ⁡ E s π k [ ∑ t = 0 ∞ γ r t ( − B ˆ k ( s t , a k , t ) | a k , t ∼ π k ) ] s . t . : E s π k [ d k − ∑ t = 0 ∞ γ c t C k ( s t , a k , t ) ] ≥ 0 where π : × k ∈ N π k is the joint policy, and the non-negative value d k j ∈ D is the safety budget for constraint of agent k. This problem can be rewritten as an equivalent max-min problem using the Lagrangian approach [31]: (39) max π ⁡ min λ ≥ 0 ⁡ J ˆ ≜ max π k , 1 ≤ k ≤ N ⁡ min λ ≥ 0 ⁡ E s π k [ ∑ t = 0 ∞ γ r t ( − B ˆ k ( s t , a k , t ) | a k , t ∼ π k ) ] + λ E s π k [ d k j − ∑ t = 0 ∞ γ c t C k ( s t , a k , t ) ] where C k ( ⋅ ) is described in Section 4.1. Besides, four metrics are established assess the algorithm's regulation performance: (1) Average voltage deviation V d ( p . u . ) : It is expressed as the average voltage deviation away from 1 p.u. for each bus per time step. (2) Carbon emission C L ( gC O 2 ) : It calculates the average carbon emission for all smart buildings per time step. (3) Reactive power loss P L ( kWh ) : It calculates the average reactive power loss of each bus per time step. (4) Total line loss P T L ( kWh ) : It calculates the average of the total power loss over all buses per time step. We evolve 1000 epochs based on dataset D d a t a 2 , each epoch containing 96 steps (i.e., 24 hours). The regulation results are shown in Table 5 . Strategies trained via the CMARL-EX approach demonstrate superiority over other algorithms in metrics such as average carbon emissions, average voltage deviation and reactive power loss measurements. This indicates the proposed algorithm's capability to emulate the latent intent of expert joint strategies in energy management, offering reliable strategies for the construction of green buildings with efficient carbon reduction. Such an approach is particularly pivotal in ecologically fragile regions, where air pollution is a significant concern. Furthermore, as shown in Table 5 and Table 3, the CMARL-EX algorithm consistently maintains efficient online strategy learning across various target scenarios, offering energy regulation strategies that ensure high reward performance and safety. This lays the foundation for future strategic designs that are tailored to the specific needs of ecologically-disturbed locales. 5.3 Case study 2 5.3.1 Simulation setup In this case, to test the scalability of the CMARL-EX algorithm in practical settings, we selected the 86-bus distribution network situated in the northern Hebei province of China as the case study. The network's topology is depicted in Fig. 9 . Each of the 85 buses depicted in the illustration is randomly connected to a specific number of intelligent multi-agent building agents, as outlined in Section 3.2. EnergyPlus is utilized to generate the energy control scenario for smart buildings, utilizing data on regional temperature and PV capacity from northern Hebei province, China. Besides, we have two datasets D ˆ d a t a 1 and D ˆ d a t a 2 . The dataset D ˆ d a t a 1 is the building history data of one month based on building model provided in Section 3.2, which we use for the offline learning process in Section 4.3. Specifically, we utilize the February building energy demand data (28 days) from the northern Hebei climate zone in China and generate expert historical trajectories based on rule-based policies trained by offline data D ˆ d a t a 1 . To accomplish our task objectives, the preference scoring and ranking are performed using Eq. (22) based on expert preferences. The dataset D ˆ d a t a 2 is four weeks (28 days) of random summer days from the northern Hebei climate zone in China, which we use for online training and testing process. This study uses the 86-bus distribution network in the northern Hebei province of China as a grid model and simulates it with the pandapower library. 5.3.2 Algorithm scalability performance analysis To verify the applicability of the proposed algorithm in practical settings, we conduct experiments based on real data from the northern Hebei province of China. Additionally, to validate the scalability of the algorithm in large-scale systems, comparative experiments are conducted in scenarios with 85 (one building for each bus) and 255 (three buildings for each bus) smart buildings. The same evaluation metrics as in Section 5.2 are used to assess the proposed algorithm's energy management performance. In the case, two scales of smart building systems are considered. We only evolve 1000 epochs based on dataset D ˆ d a t a 2 , each epoch containing 32 steps (i.e., 8h). The regulation results are shown in Table 6 . As shown in Table 3 and Table 6, with the increasing scale of smart building agents, the policy trained by CMARL-EX algorithm consistently demonstrates superior performance with respect to average voltage deviation measure, net electricity consumption measure and power loss measure. The growing complexity of interactions among smart buildings in large-scale energy management systems makes the MARL algorithm insufficient for swiftly identifying control strategies that satisfy multiple task objectives under safety constraints. In contrast, the CMARL-EX algorithm, which combines CMARL and imitation learning, effectively captures the underlying intention of learning from expert strategies, adaptively defines non-linear reward functions, and thereby enhances the control effectiveness of energy management for smart buildings within distribution networks. 6 Conclusions In this paper, the energy management optimization problem for smart buildings with PV inverters and energy storage systems is considered. By establishing safety constraints, utilizing imitation learning to configure reward functions and designing the target value competition, a safe constrained MARL algorithm called CMARL-EX is proposed. This algorithm not only tackles voltage safety concerns during online strategy training but also achieves optimization of multiple task objectives. To assess the efficacy of CMARL-EX, we present a theoretical analysis and conduct case studies using real-world data. The results demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed algorithm in both online training and execution. Furthermore, we compare the robustness and efficiency of CMARL-EX with various existing algorithms, highlighting its ability to offer a reliable and effective solution for integrating MARL into energy management tasks for smart buildings. coredata.dc:description: The rapid urbanization and increasing use of distributed renewable energy resources have imposed a significant burden on power networks. Smart buildings equipped with artificial intelligence technology can play a pivotal role in energy management, ultimately enhancing energy efficiency and voltage quality. However, ensuring voltage stability within large-scale smart building systems presents challenges due to the coexistence of diverse energy sources and the fluctuating nature of renewable energy. This paper proposes a safe multi-energy management framework achieved by online decentralized execution and centralized training for large scale smart buildings in distribution networks. The energy management problem is formulated as a safety-augmented Markov decision process, presenting intractability for dynamic programming due to its extensive continuous state space. To solve this issue and improve the convergence speed and training process stability, a safety-augmented constrained multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithm based on reward extrapolation is proposed. In this algorithm, hazard values are introduced to enhance non-safe multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithms and meet safety constraints. A novel reward network is designed by imitating expert underlying intentions to ensure the rationality of the reward function for multi-objective tasks. Additionally, the loss function for estimating the Q-network is redesigned during training process to guarantee effective convergence. Theoretical analysis is conducted to provide the convergence guarantee. Numerical case studies based on actual data are performed to validate the effectiveness and scalability of our approach, showing that smart buildings can achieve superior energy management performance while ensuring voltage safety for distribution networks. The source code of the proposed algorithm is available at https://github.com/SYiyun/CMARL-EX.
